fa: Standard Oil and Royal Dutch Shell carved up Persia like a birthday cake, bribing the Shah for oil concessions.

middle.actor: British diplomat (anonymous but smug as hell)
middle.quote: 'It's just sand and carpets out here. Let us handle the boring black goo.'

fo: Persia got pennies; the West got barrels. Result? A century of coups, wars, CIA meddling, sanctions, and an entire region on fire while ExxonMobil and BP still pop champagne on your fuel money.

fa: India gained independence from Britain, but London left behind a flaming mess called 'Partition' — Pakistan vs. India.

middle.quote: 'We'll just draw a neat line on a map, problem solved.'

fo: Result? Millions dead, trains full of corpses, decades of blood feuds, nukes aimed across borders, and the world's spiciest rivalry — all because the British couldn't manage a polite exit.

fa: Iran's Prime Minister Mossadegh dared to nationalize oil, kicking out BP. CIA + MI6 said 'hold my whiskey' and staged a coup.

middle.quote: 'Operation Ajax: democracy is cute, but oil is cuter.'

fo: Shah reinstalled like a corporate puppet, SAVAK police torturing dissenters, and the West got cheap oil — until 1979 when Iran went full ayatollah mode. Thanks, Langley.

fa: Chile elects socialist Salvador Allende. CIA + Kissinger: 'Nah, we prefer fascist generals with sunglasses.' Coup incoming.

middle.quote: 'I don't see why we need to stand by and watch a country go communist due to the irresponsibility of its people.'

fo: Allende dead, Pinochet in power, thousands disappeared, and Chile's economy sold to Chicago Boys like a neoliberal yard sale. Kissinger still got a Nobel Prize — comedy gold.

fa: Rwanda genocide: UN wagged fingers, NATO shrugged, France played double agent. A million dead while the world argued about 'mandates.'

middle.quote: 'We are monitoring the situation very closely.'

fo: Monitoring = watching machetes swing on CNN. Western powers intervened late, if at all, because Rwanda had no oil. But hey, lots of guilt-ridden memoirs got published after.
